column1: Daily-instantaneous 3-d atmosphere data for selected years (longitude, latitude, model levels, time:day)
column2: Instantaneous O3 is requested for the first day at 00:00 UTC for each month of the whole run.

Instantaneous data at 0 UTC is requested on (or as near to) the 1st, 11th, 21st each month, for: 1) all years between 1990-2010. 2) every 3-years before 1989 (e.g., 1960, 1963, 1966,..). 3) every 3-years from 2005 (e.g., 2005, 2008, 2011,...)
Instantaneous data at 0,6,12,18 UTC is requested for the the following time periods for aircraft campaign comparison:

column1: Daily-instantaneous 3-d atmosphere data for selected time periods (longitude, latitude, model levels, time:day) and reduced vertical levels: 500 hPa-5 hPa

column10: Notes
The atmospheric pressure at the model layer midpoints for all times and levels in the associated output variables
The atmospheric pressure at the model layer interfaces for all times and levels in the associated output variables
omega

Passive O3 (if available): The model runs should include a tracer to diagnose polar chemical ozone loss in winter and spring. As most models will advect (and integrate) O3 as part of the 'odd oxygen' (Ox=O3 + O(3P) + O(1D)) family we will call this the 'passive Ox tracer'. This will be a global tracer which is reset during each polar winter (i.e. twice per year). Given the relatively slow transport and long chemical lifetime (without PSC processing etc) of O3 in the polar regions this will provide a useful diagnostic over the timescale of a few months in the lower stratosphere. The model tracer should be set equal to your advected 'odd oxygen' tracer on December 1 and June 1 every year. Then, the tracer is simply advected without any further chemical change. If your advection scheme stores other variables for each tracer (e.g. higher order moments) remember to set sum of these species. The passive Ox tracer should be ouput according to the other instructions. The re-initialisation dates are selected so that we diagnose most of the chemical loss over the course of the winter, some of which would be missed by a later date.

column2: Surface Area Density of Sulfate Aerosol
column10: sulfate aerosol surface area density used in heterogeneous activation of ClOx and BrOx. Defined as the area of aerosol per volume of atmosphere (i.e., m2 m-3 = m-1). This is the total sulfate SAD (i.e., sum of binary and ternary aerosol).

column2: Surface Area Density of NAT PSC Particles
column10: nitric acid trihydrate (NAT) surface area density used in heterogeneous activation of ClOx and BrOx. Defined as the area of aerosol per volume of atmosphere (i.e., m2 m-3 = m-1).

column2: Surface Area Density of Water Ice PSC Particles
column10: water-ice surface area density used in heterogeneous activation of ClOx and BrOx. Defined as the area of aerosol per volume of atmosphere (i.e., m2 m-3 = m-1).

column2: Total Inorganic Chlorine (Cly) Volume Mixing Ratio
column10: Total family (the sum of all appropriate species in the model) ; list the species in the netCDF header, e.g. Cly = HCl + ClONO2 + HOCl + ClO + Cl + 2*Cl2O2 +2Cl2 + OClO + BrCl.  Definition: Total inorganic stratospheric chlorine (e.g., HCl, ClO) resulting from degradation of chlorine-containing source gases (CFCs, HCFCs, VSLS), and natural inorganic chlorine sources (e.g., sea salt and other aerosols).

column2: Total Reactive Nitrogen (NOy) Volume Mixing Ratio
column10: Total family (the sum of all appropriate species in the model); list the species in the netCDF header, e.g. NOy = N + NO + NO2 + NO3 + HNO3 + 2N2O5 + HNO4 + ClONO2 + BrONO2.  Definition: Total reactive nitrogen; usually includes atomic nitrogen (N), nitric oxide (NO), NO2, nitrogen trioxide (NO3), dinitrogen radical (N2O5), nitric acid (HNO3), peroxynitric acid (HNO4), BrONO2, ClONO2.

column2: Total Inorganic Bromine (Bry) Volume Mixing Ratio
column10: Total family (the sum of all appropriate species in the model) ; list the species in the netCDF header, e.g. Bry = Br + BrO + HOBr + HBr + BrONO2 + BrCl.  Definition: Total inorganic bromine (e.g., HBr and inorganic bromine oxides and radicals (e.g., BrO, atomic bromine (Br), bromine nitrate (BrONO2)) resulting from degradation of bromine-containing organic source gases (halons, methyl bromide, VSLS), and natural inorganic bromine sources (e.g., volcanoes, sea salt, and other aerosols).
The mean age of air is defined as the mean time that a stratospheric air mass has been out of contact with the well-mixed troposphere.
shortwave heating rates
longwave heating rates
Include both large-scale and convective cloud.
Convective cloud fraction

Ozone tracer intended to map out strat-trop exchange (STE) of ozone: (a) set o3ste to O3 at top layer; (b) use standard O3 P-L terms to change o3ste every chemistry time step for 'stratospheric' air grid boxes; (c) reset o3ste to O3 in the lowermost layers (fix these layers to be up to sigma=0.9, ~1 km altitude) and record this tropospheric reset only as a 2-D (lat,long) monthly mean tendency (Tg/s or Tg per month pergird cell).  Determine 'stratospheric' air in any way that is most convenient (e90, O3, PV-theta, etc).

Synthetic tracer e90 has 90-day e-fold everywhere; emitted uniformly (g/m2) over all land/ocean/ice; see Prather et al. 2011 JGR 116, D04306, doi:10.1029/2010JD014939; any normalization can be used if defined, but UCI chooses: mol.wt = 28.97(dry air), emissions = 2074 Tg/y (kg/m2/s) , thus steady-state mean mole fraction = 100 ppb (for ECMWF dry air mass).
Synthetic tracer e90n, same as e90, but emitted only 40N to 90N.
Synthetic tracer e90s, same as e90, but emitted only 40S to 90S.
